DOCNAME: VAN DEN BOUWHUIJSEN and SCHURING v. THE NETHERLANDS
TEXT: The applicants , PERSON and PERSON , are mother and daughter . They are GPE nationals , born in DATE and DATE respectively , and live in PERSON , the GPE . They are represented before the ORG by PERSON A.M.W. PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The first applicant cohabited with her partner , Mr GPE , from DATE until the latter ’s death in DATE . They were not married . On DATE a daughter , Jolien – the second applicant DATE was born to the couple . Mr GPE legally recognised his daughter and , following a decision by ORG ( kantonrechter ) of CARDINAL DATE , both parents were invested with parental authority over ORG .

On DATE , following the death of Mr Schuring , the first applicant requested a survivor ’s benefit on behalf of ORG from ORG ( ORG ) pursuant to ORG and LAW ( Algemene Weduwen- en Wezenwet ; “ AWW ” ) . In her request she acknowledged that under the provisions of the AWW she herself was not entitled to a widow ’s pension as she had not been married to Mr Schuring . However , as her daughter had been financially dependent on her father , she laid claim , on behalf of her daughter , to benefits to the amount of PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage . In the subsequent proceedings she argued that since a widow without children was entitled to a partial widow ’s pension amounting to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage and a widow with a child under the age of CARDINAL received a full widow ’s pension amounting to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage , a child born of married parents was in effect awarded a survivor ’s benefit amounting to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage in the form of an extra allowance on top of his / her surviving parent ’s benefit . Not awarding this component of the widow ’s pension to ORG because her parents had not been married – a circumstance over which ORG had had no control – amounted to unjustified discrimination on the grounds of birth .

To substantiate her argument that the difference between a full and a partial widow ’s pension had always been intended to benefit the child who had lost CARDINAL of his / her parents , the first applicant referred to the drafting history of LAW ( PERSON ) which replaced the AWW on DATE . She also pointed to ORG no . CARDINAL ( ORG , DATE ) and no . CARDINAL ( the Invalidity , Old - Age and Survivors’ Benefits Convention , DATE ) which oblige member states to provide cash benefits to the dependent children of a breadwinner . According to the first applicant , the GPE legislator had complied with this obligation by awarding higher benefits to widows with minor children . However , by requiring that the surviving parent be married to the deceased , a dependent child born out of wedlock was excluded .

The first applicant ’s request was rejected by ORG on DATE . It held that as the first applicant had not been married to PERSON Schuring , she was not eligible for either a partial or a full widow ’s pension . Moreover , although the AWW did provide for benefits for orphans , ORG could not be awarded such benefits as she was not an orphan , one of her parents still being alive .

The first applicant ’s objection ( bezwaar ) was rejected by ORG on DATE . Her appeal ( beroep ) to ORG ( arrondissementsrechtbank ) of GPE was rejected on DATE . Finally , ORG ( ORG ) rejected the first applicant ’s appeal ( hoger beroep ) on DATE .

ORG found that no unjustified discrimination had taken place . Referring to its own case - law , it reiterated that the fact that the pension for a widow with a child under DATE was higher than that for a widow without children did not entail that that difference should be considered as a cash benefit for the child who had lost CARDINAL of his / her parents . The AWW provided for benefits for CARDINAL kinds of survivors : widows and orphans . It was only in respect of a widow ’s pension that a difference in treatment was made , in that a marriage between the deceased and the survivor was required in order to create a right to such a pension . The first applicant had not disputed that this difference in treatment was justified . The right to orphan ’s benefits was not dependent on a child having been born in wedlock but only on a child being the offspring of the deceased whose death caused the child to be without parents DATE which was not the case here . As a result , the survivors’ benefit claimed by the first applicant could only be placed in the framework of the provisions concerning widows , and the refusal to award her either a full widow ’s pension or any other widow ’s benefit could only be seen in relation to her not having been married to the deceased . There was no other discriminatory factor which could be considered as underlying the subsidiary effect that the majority of cases where an entitlement to a full widow ’s pension existed concerned children born from the marriage of the deceased to the surviving widow .

The AWW , which entered into force on DATE , insured against the risk of the death of the family breadwinner . Under the AWW scheme , all persons residing in the GPE and non - residents gainfully employed in the GPE were compulsory insured . Contributions to this scheme were paid by all persons gainfully employed in the GPE .

Entitlement to AWW benefits was not dependent on the level of contributions paid as , contrary to a social security scheme based on employment ( werknemersverzekering ) , it was a general social security scheme ( volksverzekering ) . The level of benefits was linked to the statutory minimum wage .

The AWW conferred entitlement to a widow ’s pension for the widow , who was not yet aged DATE , of an insured person provided she was caring for an unmarried child born before or on the date of the death of her spouse . A widow without children was also entitled to claim benefit , for example if she was incapacitated for work or was aged DATE or over at the time of her husband ’s death . “ Widow ” meant the woman to whom the insured person was married on the date of his death . Since DATE , widowers enjoyed the same entitlement to benefit after the death of their wives on the basis of case - law .

As it was felt that a widow with children had greater financial needs than a widow without children ( see Bijlagen Handelingen Tweede Kamer – Appendices to ORG DATE , CARDINAL , DATE ) , a widow with unmarried children under DATE regardless of their number – received an amount equal to the minimum wage whereas a widow without children received PERCENT of that amount .

Under the AWW the unmarried child , up to the age of DATE , of the deceased person was entitled to an orphan ’s benefit provided the child had lost both parents or if the surviving parent had been divested of parental authority .

The AWW was repealed on DATE and replaced by LAW ( PERSON ) . The new LAW replaced the term ‘ widow’ by ‘ surviving partner’ , this being the person who was married to the deceased person or who was in a relationship of equivalent status with him or her .
